Mariam was five when she first heard the word harami. 

It was a Thursday. She remembered because she always felt restless on Thursdays, the day Jalil visited her at the kolba (a small house). To kill time before he arrived, Mariam climbed onto a chair and grabbed her mom's Chinese tea set. This was the only thing Mariam's mom, Nana, had from her own mother, who died when Nana was just two. Nana loved every piece of that blue-and-white porcelain setâ€”the potâ€™s elegant spout, the hand-painted finches and chrysanthemums, and the dragon on the sugar bowl meant to keep evil away. 

But then, the sugar bowl slipped from Mariam's hands and shattered on the wooden floor. 

When Nana saw the broken bowl, her face turned red, and her lip trembled. Her eyesâ€”both the lazy one and the good oneâ€”fixed on Mariam in a cold, unblinking stare. Nana looked so furious that Mariam worried the jinn (a spirit) would come back. But it didnâ€™t happen this time. Instead, Nana yanked Mariam by the wrists, pulled her close, and, through gritted teeth, spat out, â€œYou are a clumsy little harami. This is my reward for everything Iâ€™ve enduredâ€”an heirloom-breaking, clumsy little harami.â€ 

At that moment, Mariam didnâ€™t get it. She didnâ€™t know what haramiâ€”bastardâ€”meant. She was too young to see the unfairness of it, that the blame lay with the people who made her a harami, not with her, who had done nothing wrong except be born. But she sensed from Nanaâ€™s tone that being a harami was something disgusting, like the cockroaches Nana always cursed and swept away. 

As she grew older, Mariam began to understand. It was the way Nana spat the word that made its sting hit hard. She realized that a harami was unwanted; that she, Mariam, was an illegitimate person who would never have the same rights to love, family, home, or acceptance as others. 

Jalil never called her that. He called her his little flower. He loved to sit her on his lap and tell her stories, like how Herat, where Mariam was born in 1959, was once the heart of Persian culture, home to writers, painters, and Sufis.
